title: Question 38

children: An 85-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital after surgical fixation of a broken hip. He reports a mild level of pain. He did not bring his glasses or hearing aids to the hospital. He has been making progress with physical therapy and, when his pain is controlled, he will be transferred to an inpatient rehabilitation facility. His history includes high-frequency hearing loss, macular degeneration, and hypertension. Medications are lisinopril and chlorthalidone.
On physical examination, vital signs and other findings are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate measure to prevent delirium?

text.__html: Monitoring of vital signs every 2 hours
Use of his glasses and hearing aids

children: Identifying and correcting sensory impairments, including providing patients with their visual and hearing aids, is effective in the prevention of delirium.
This patient's glasses and hearing aids should be provided to him to prevent delirium (
Option E

). Delirium is a potentially preventable syndrome associated with other medical disorders, the adverse effects of medication, or drug withdrawal. It is common in hospitalized patients, and elderly patients such as this one are at higher risk postsurgery. Delirium is associated with increases in morbidity, medical complications, hospital length of stay, and rate of discharge to long-term care facilities; prevention is more effective than treatment of delirium, especially in at-risk patients. Identifying and correcting sensory impairments, including providing patients with their visual and hearing aids, is an environmental modification that has been shown to be effective in the prevention of delirium.
Early mobilization prevents delirium, so the patient does not need bedrest (
Option A
) outside of physical therapy.
Checking vital signs every 2 hours would entail awakening the patient throughout the night (
Option B

). Because altered circadian rhythm is a component of the clinical syndrome of delirium, promoting a normal sleep-wake cycle by limiting interruptions during nocturnal sleeping hours, minimizing light and noise at night, and opening curtains and encouraging activity during the daytime is an important element in the prevention of delirium. Finally, frequent monitoring of vital signs may provide early detection of changes in clinical status but will not prevent delirium.

No medication is currently approved by the FDA for the management of delirium, so the use of these agents for such an indication is off-label. Furthermore, there is no strong evidence that any particular drug is useful for delirium prevention. Melatonin may assist in maintaining the sleep-wake cycle. Unless patients are at risk of harm to themselves or others, antipsychotic agents such as quetiapine (
Option C
) should be avoided because psychoactive and sedating medications can contribute to the development of delirium.
Scheduled morphine administration (
Option D
) is likely to overtreat the patient's pain and lead to sedation. It is important to treat pain, but pain should be managed using the least sedating agents possible in patients at risk for delirium.

objective.__html: Prevent delirium in a hospitalized patient.

references: Marcantonio ER. Delirium in hospitalized older adults. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:1456-66.
